p.note: The clasical form would be añmassu (43); aimasu is probably a late variant of it, although the precise status of the variant āyme of the base word āñme 'soul, self' has not been settled yet (cf. 159-60). Most forms are from late texts or texts with late features: : a5 āymtsa (late), : a1 āymesa (late), : a3 āyme (fragmentary), : a5 āym° ? (late), : b5 āym (Tocharian text fragmentary). The problem is that we also find one archaic attestation: : b4 aymäntse. A similar variation is found with añmālaṣke 'pitying' and the derived abstract: : b1 aym(ā)lāṣke (perhaps arch.), : a5 āymelaṣkäññesa (a text with both arch. and late features).
The classical form would be kāwälñesa (as in : b3 kāwälñemeṃ, though we also find kāwalyñesa): note the late simplification of lñ to ñ and the spelling of wä as wa.
glosses Skt. Bc.2.49d hiṃsrā° 'cruel, murderous', a text variant found in this fragment, the correct reading of the Buddhacarita text being rather hiṃsā° 'injury' (60; I, 18).
Note late ram for class. ramt. Conversely, the vocalism of ñäkte seems clear and the expected late ñikte is not found.

glosses Skt. Bc.2.51d (ka) iv 'like Ka'. Apparently the glossator preferred to replace Ka with the more common Brahman. A tiny piece of paper seems to cover the upper left stroke of the p. A trace of a further gloss is found right of ram\ under Bc.2.51d ād(ikale) 'in the beginning'.

The first item seems to gloss Skt. Bc.2.52d dadarśa 'he regarded' (55), if we understand it as an explanatory gloss clarifying that dadarśa here effectively means 'reigned over'. Schmidt apud 60 reads (pe)lkiṃ, but no anusvāra is visible; the dot to the left of the l probably belongs to the body of the l.

The second item glosses Skt. Bc.2.53a babhā(ra), here 'fostered' (55), 'maintained' (II, 30), and is written a little higher than tāka, the last word of the gloss to the left (see above), and so apparently does not belong to it.

yamate is no regular form of any known Tocharian B verb. Closest in form would seem to be yamaṣṣate 'he did', for which it could be a mistake. If so, this would at once explain why the first and second syllable both have short a: in a regular non-causative preterite the second should be long, in a regular causative preterite the first. This mistake may have been favoured by the fact that in the late language the classical preterite with a 3sg.mid. yamaṣṣate had developed into a shorter stem with a 3sg.mid. maṣṣate* (the late stem is so far only attested in the active, i.e. 3sg. maṣṣa; 160). yam- 'do' is frequently used in phrasal verbs, and was probably used with a preceding frozen noun here as well, even though a suitable combination is not attested so far (cf. ).
glosses Skt. Bc.2.53d (āca)kāṃkṣe (v.l. of ācakāṅkṣa, I, 19) 'expected, desired' (55, 'sought').
A further, fainter gloss is found to the right, starting with ra ///.
